questions.text: Which of these options is not a causal factor for head and neck malignancies? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin A deficiency

 

Vitamin A deficiency is not recognized as a direct risk factor for head and neck malignancies. While vitamin A plays crucial roles in maintaining epithelial tissues and immune function, its deficiency primarily leads to issues like night blindness and immune deficiencies, rather than directly causing cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus) infection: EBV is associated with various types of cancers, including nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It is a well-established risk factor for this specific type of head and neck cancer.

 

Option B. HPV (Human Papillomavirus) infection: HPV, particularly type 16, is a significant risk factor for oropharyngeal cancers. The virus can lead to cellular transformations that result in malignancy.

 

Option Betel nut: Consumption of betel nut, often part of a "paan" or betel quid, is a known risk factor for oral cancers, particularly in the gingivobuccal sulcus, common in regions where it is a cultural practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common risk factors known to cause head and neck malignancies includes:

 

  1. Alcohol use
  2. Tobacco use (smoking or chewing)
  3. Viruses
    1. HPV 16 - oropharyngeal cancer
    2. EBV – Nasopharyngeal cancer
  4. Paan (betel quid) – Oral cancers especially in gingivobuccal sulcus
  5. Preserved or salted food consumption - nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  6. Occupational exposure:
    1. Exposure to wood or nickel dust or formaldehyde - a risk factor for cancers of the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity
    2. Radiation exposure is a risk factor for salivary gland tumors, thyroid gland carcinoma

questions.text: A female singer with hoarseness of voice, unable to sing higher frequency notes. Bowed and depressed unilateral vocal cord is seen. Which muscle is involved? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricothyroid

  

The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for tensing the vocal cords, which allows for the production of higher frequency sounds. When the vocal cords are tightly stretched, they vibrate at a higher frequency, which is necessary for producing high-pitched notes.

 

In this scenario, the female singer is unable to sing higher frequency notes, indicating that her vocal cords are not adequately tense. This suggests paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, which normally maintains the tension of the vocal cords. If the cricothyroid muscle is paralyzed, typically due to damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, the vocal cords become bowed, loose, and floppy, impairing the ability to produce high-frequency sounds.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior cricoarytenoid: This muscle is the only abductor of the vocal cords, which means it separates the vocal cords during breathing. It does not contribute to tensing the vocal cords for high-frequency sound production.

 

Option B. Thyroarytenoid: This muscle acts as both an adductor and a relaxer of the vocal cords, contributing to lowering the pitch of the voice rather than raising it. It does not tense the vocal cords and, therefore, does not aid in the production of higher frequency notes.

 

Option D. Interarytenoid: This muscle functions as an adductor, helping to bring the vocal cords together. It does not have a role in tensing the vocal cords for higher frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cricothyroid muscle is essential for producing high-frequency notes by tensing the vocal cords. Paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle leads to the inability to produce these higher notes due to a lack of tension in the vocal cords.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with left-sided headache and facial pressure. CT scan shows complete opacification of the sinus as shown by the arrow. (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontal sinus

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows complete opacification of the frontal sinus with:

 

  • Blocked frontal recess
  • Mucosal thickening
  • Air-fluid level
  • Classic appearance of frontal sinusitis with outflow obstruction
  • Superior location in relation to orbit

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maxillary sinus:

Located inferior to the orbit and lateral to the nasal cavity, which doesn't match the location shown in the image.

 

Option B. Ethmoid sinus:

Located between the orbits in a honeycomb pattern, not matching the single large air space shown in the image.

 

Option D. Sphenoid sinus:

Located posterior to ethmoid air cells, not visible in this coronal plane at this level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To identify the frontal sinus on coronal CT imaging and recognize the radiological appearance of frontal sinusitis with outflow tract obstruction, which can lead to serious complications if left untreated due to its proximity to the brain.

questions.text: A surgeon wants to perform frozen section analysis during total thyroidectomy to rule out malignancy. Which staining technique would be most appropriate? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) H&E

 

Explanation: 

 

H&E (Hematoxylin and Eosin) staining is the gold standard for frozen section analysis during thyroid surgery. It provides excellent nuclear and cytoplasmic detail necessary for identifying malignant changes in thyroid tissue. Hematoxylin stains nuclear material blue/purple while eosin stains cytoplasmic components pink/red, allowing clear visualization of cellular architecture and nuclear features crucial for diagnosing thyroid malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supravital staining (like Toluidine blue): While useful for in-vivo examination during laryngoscopy, it's not suitable for frozen sections as it doesn't provide the detailed cellular architecture needed for definitive diagnosis of thyroid malignancy.

 

Option C. Congo red: This special stain is specifically used to identify amyloid deposits. It has no role in routine frozen section analysis of thyroid tissue for malignancy.

 

Option D. Silver nitrate: This is primarily used as a cauterizing agent and for highlighting reticular fibers. It's not suitable for routine frozen section analysis where nuclear and cytoplasmic details are crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand that H&E staining remains the standard technique for frozen section analysis during thyroid surgery, providing necessary detail for identifying malignant changes, unlike supravital stains which are better suited for in-vivo examination.

questions.text: A young woman, aged 25, presented with hearing impairment that emerged shortly after her initial pregnancy. Provided below is her audiometry findings. What could be the potential diagnosis for this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otosclerosis

 

Hearing loss that developed shortly after the first pregnancy along with Carhart's notch seen in the audiogram is suggestive of otosclerosis.

 

Interpretation of the given audiogram:

 

  • Blue color indicates the left ear.
  • x indicates AC and threshold is >15 dB and hence AC is abnormal. So it indicates conductive deafness.
  • ] indicates BC and threshold is <25dB. A characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz called Carhart’s notch is seen.
  • The air-bone gap is a feature of conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence, left-sided otosclerosis is the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Ototoxicity causes SNHL and shows a high-frequency hearing loss in the SNHL curve.

 

Option B: Meniere's disease shows a low-frequency loss in the SNHL curve.

 

 

Option D: Noise-induced hearing loss - PTA shows a characteristic Acoustic dip at 4000 Hz (Boiler’s Notch).

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A gentleman presents to the OPD with a saddle nose deformity. He gives a past history of cough, on/off fever, and hemoptysis. On examination, septal perforation is present with pale granuloma. His chest x-ray showed multiple cavitary lesions, and the biopsy showed granuloma, multinucleated giant cells, and caseous necrosis. What would be the probable cause? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

Generalized symptoms of fever, productive cough, weight loss, night sweats, and hemoptysis along with chest x-ray showing multiple cavitation lesions are suggestive of tuberculosis. This diagnosis is supported by:

 

  • Chest X-ray: Presence of multiple cavitary lesions, which are characteristic of pulmonary TB.
  • Biopsy Findings: The presence of granulomas, multinucleated giant cells (Langhans type), and caseous necrosis is indicative of TB, which involves granulomatous inflammation with a distinctive type of necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wegener's Granulomatosis: This could also present with nasal deformity and granulomas but is usually associated with vasculitis and lacks the caseous necrosis typical of TB.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Can cause nasal collapse ("saddle nose") but typically does not present with the lung involvement seen in TB.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Also presents with granulomas but lacks the caseous necrosis seen in TB and typically shows non-cavitary lung lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis should be considered in patients presenting with respiratory symptoms, systemic signs, and nasal deformities when accompanied by histological evidence of caseating granulomas. This constellation of findings is distinct in suggesting TB over other granulomatous diseases.

 

Granulomatous Disease of the Nose:

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the emergency department with sudden onset dysphagia. The chest x-ray shows a radiopaque object in the upper esophagus as shown in the image 1. The object has been present for approximately 6 hours, and the child now has developed stridor. What is the sign known as depicted in image 2? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Steeple sign

 

The x-ray initially shows a button battery lodged in the esophagus with the characteristic double ring sign. However, after 6 hours of impaction, the caustic damage from the battery has led to subglottic edema, resulting in the development of a steeple sign on the same x-ray. The steeple sign appears as a symmetrical tapering of the subglottic airway, creating a spire-like appearance. This is a critical finding as it indicates the development of secondary airway compromise due to the prolonged presence of the battery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. String sign: This refers to a thin, linear lucency seen in bowel obstruction or Crohn's disease, not applicable to upper airway pathology.

 

Option B. Double ring sign: While this sign is visible due to the button battery, the question specifically asks about the complication that has developed, which is airway compromise.

 

Option C. Halo sign: This refers to a radiological finding typically seen in invasive aspergillosis of the lung, showing a lucent ring around a nodular opacity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To recognize that button battery ingestion can lead to rapid complications including airway compromise, and the importance of identifying both the primary foreign body and its secondary complications on imaging.

questions.text: On the promontory, behind the tympanic membrane, there is a red mass originating within the middle ear. CT is given. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glomus tympanicum

 

Explanation:

 

The CT scan shows a mass located on the promontory behind the tympanic membrane, which is typical of a glomus tympanicum, NOT glomus jugulare.

 

Key points:

 

  • Glomus tympanicum arises on the promontory along the course of Jacobson’s nerve (tympanic branch of IX cranial nerve).
  • It is the most common benign middle ear neoplasm.
  • It appears as a red mass behind the intact tympanic membrane, producing a pulsatile red reflex.
  • CT shows a soft tissue mass confined to the middle ear without erosion of the caroticojugular spine.
  • Glomus jugulare, in contrast, originates from the dome of the jugular bulb, grows into the hypotympanum and jugular foramen, and typically erodes the caroticojugular spine (the “phelp sign”).

 

In CT image, there is no obvious erosion of the caroticojugular spine, and the mass is confined to the middle ear promontory, confirming glomus tympanicum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glomus jugulare: Incorrect here — because the tumour is limited to the middle ear promontory without signs of extension into the jugular bulb or jugular foramen. There is no caroticojugular spine erosion.

 

Option C. Otosclerosis: Does not appear as a mass. It causes abnormal bone deposition near the stapes, leading to conductive hearing loss but not a visible mass.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect — because the finding matches glomus tympanicum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A red mass on the promontory behind an intact tympanic membrane, with no erosion of the caroticojugular spine, indicates glomus tympanicum.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 109

choices.text: Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. On examination, the doctor diagnose Otosclerosis and recommends stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests based on which the doctor has recommended stapedectomy? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Typical of otosclerosis, indicating conductive hearing loss where BC > AC.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Indicates that the sound is heard better in the ear with more conductive loss, which matches otosclerosis more severely affecting the right ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Indicates that air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC), which is a normal finding and typically not expected in conductive hearing loss like otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: In a case of unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss, Weber's test lateralizes to the better hearing ear in sensorineural hearing loss and to the poorer ear in conductive hearing loss. This pattern does not fit otosclerosis affecting the right ear more severely.

 

Option B. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Again, indicates normal AC > BC, not typical for otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Would suggest either a sensorineural hearing loss on the left ear or less likely conductive loss on the right, which doesn’t match typical otosclerosis findings.

 

Option C. Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Indicates that BC > AC, suggesting conductive hearing loss, typical of otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: Would imply the left ear is either better or has conductive loss, not aligning with greater hearing loss in the right ear due to otosclerosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of a negative Rinne test and Weber test lateralizing to the ear with more hearing loss is indicative of conductive hearing loss in that ear. In otosclerosis, the ossification of the stapes leads to mechanical dysfunction, preventing effective sound transmission, hence a stapedectomy might be recommended to mechanically bypass the ossified stapes and improve hearing.

choices.text: Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

questions.text: A patient present with oral cavity findings as seen in the image below. He is a smoker. What would you choose as your next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

 

  • The next step of management of this patient will be cessation of smoking and do a biopsy.
  • The patient is a chronic smoker and the following image shows leukoplakia. Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity.

 

The management include: 

 

  1. Elimination of associated aetiological factors and biopsy of the lesion. Many of the lesions will disappear spontaneously if the causative agent is removed.
  2. In lesions with higher potential for malignant change, a biopsy is taken to rule out malignancy.
  3. In suspicious small lesions, surgical excision or ablation with laser or cryotherapy can be done.

 

A photographic record of the lesion is useful for long term follow up.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give corticosteroids: There is no role for corticosteroids in the treatment of leukoplakia as they do not address the potential for malignant transformation or the underlying causes of the lesion.

 

Option C. Lifestyle Modifications: While beneficial overall, lifestyle changes alone are insufficient for managing a lesion with potential malignancy. Specific interventions like quitting smoking are required.

 

Option D. Injection vitamin B12: There is no indication that vitamin B12 injections would be effective in treating leukoplakia unless there is a specific deficiency that also needs addressing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For leukoplakia, particularly in smokers, the primary management strategy includes cessation of smoking and histological examination through biopsy. This is crucial not only to assess the current state of the lesion but also to guide further therapeutic decisions which may include surgical excision, laser ablation, or cryotherapy depending on the biopsy results. Regular monitoring and photographic documentation of the lesion are also important for long-term follow-up.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 253

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with progressive dyspnea and stridor 3 months after recovery from severe COVID-19 requiring prolonged ICU stay. Endoscopic evaluation reveals the finding shown in the image, along with significant circumferential scarring and calcification. The most appropriate classification system for this condition would be: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) McCaffrey

 

The image shows subglottic stenosis, but the presence of significant circumferential scarring and calcification suggests a complex stenosis that extends beyond the subglottis. The McCaffrey classification is most appropriate here as it takes into account:

 

  • The vertical extent of stenosis
  • The presence of associated scarring
  • Involvement of cartilage
  • Multiple levels of involvement

 

McCaffrey staging system: Stage I: Isolated subglottic/tracheal stenosis < 1cm Stage II: Subglottic/tracheal stenosis > 1cm Stage III: Subglottic/tracheal stenosis with glottic involvement Stage IV: Any stenosis with severe comorbidity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cotton Meyer: While commonly used for pediatric subglottic stenosis, it primarily focuses on the degree of luminal obstruction without accounting for the complexity and extent of scarring.

 

Option C. Myer-Cotton: This is the same as Cotton-Meyer classification, just written differently.

 

Option D. Bogdasarian: This classification is specifically used for posterior glottic stenosis, not for subglottic stenosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand that while Cotton-Meyer classification is widely used for simple subglottic stenosis, complex cases with extensive scarring and multi-level involvement may be better classified using the McCaffrey system, which considers additional factors beyond just the degree of stenosis.

choices.text: Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of high tracheostomy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

 

A high tracheostomy is done above the level of thyroid isthmus (isthmus lies against II, III and IV tracheal rings). It violates the first ring of trachea. Tracheostomy at this site can cause perichondritis of the cricoid cartilage and subglottic stenosis and is always avoided.

 

Only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx because in such cases, the total larynx anyway would ultimately be removed and a fresh tracheostome made in a clean area lower down.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord palsy - Not an indication for high tracheostomy as it does not necessitate altering the anatomy at the level of the isthmus or above.

 

Option B. Tracheomalacia - This condition, characterized by a weakness of the tracheal support cartilage, does not require a high tracheostomy. Treatment usually involves support lower in the trachea.

 

Option C. Foreign body obstruction - Removal of a foreign body typically does not require a high tracheostomy. This procedure would be too high to effectively clear an obstruction that is likely situated lower in the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High tracheostomy is specifically indicated for suspicion of laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery, as this condition requires eventual removal of the larynx, allowing for the creation of a fresh tracheostome in a new, clean area.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 359

choices.text: Making him sit in front row in class

questions.text: A child has bilateral SNHL. Which of the following is not preferred in the child?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

 

Adenoidectomy with Grommet Insertion: This procedure is primarily used to treat chronic adenoiditis and otitis media with effusion (OME), which are associated with conductive hearing loss (CHL), not SNHL. Since the child has SNHL, this treatment is not appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) indicates that there is a problem in the inner ear (cochlea) or the auditory nerve. When treating bilateral SNHL in a child, certain interventions are preferred based on the underlying pathology and the severity of the hearing loss.

 

Option A. Cochlear Implant: This is a viable option for children with severe to profound SNHL where the cochlea is affected but the auditory nerve is intact. The implant bypasses the damaged cochlea and directly stimulates the auditory nerve, allowing the child to hear.

 

Option C. Making him sit in front row in class: This is a common accommodation to help children with hearing loss to better hear and engage in classroom activities. It minimizes the distance between the child and the teacher, thus reducing the impact of hearing loss.

 

Option D.  Hearing Aid: This is suitable for children with mild to moderate SNHL. Hearing aids amplify sounds, making them louder and easier to hear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is not preferred for treating bilateral sensorineural hearing loss as it addresses conditions causing conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: Identify the sinus marked in the given image: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Maxillary sinus

 

Marked structure is Maxillary sinus on a non-contrast CT.

 

The Maxillary sinus is one of the largest of the paranasal sinuses and is located in the maxillary bone under the eyes, bilaterally to the nasal cavity. On imaging, such as a non-contrast CT scan, the maxillary sinus is typically visible as a large, air-filled space below the orbits (eye sockets) and lateral to the nasal cavity.

 

Following images show paranasal sinuses and related structures:

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ethmoid Sinus: Located between the nose and the eyes, within the ethmoid bone. It is a collection of small air cells.
  • Frontal Sinus: Located above the eyes, in the frontal bone. These are typically well above the maxillary sinuses.
  • Sphenoid Sinus: Located deeper and more centrally behind the nasal cavity, in the sphenoid bone.
  • Maxillary Sinus: Located beneath the orbits, on either side of the nose.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male heavy smoker presents with progressive hoarseness and inability to project his voice while teaching. Laryngoscopy reveals a unilateral immobile, lateralized vocal cord in the paramedian position. Which muscle is most likely involved? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior cricoarytenoid

 

Explanation: 

 

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is the only abductor of the vocal cords. When paralyzed, it results in:

  • Inability to abduct the vocal cord
  • Vocal cord remains in paramedian position
  • Difficulty with voice projection
  • Breathiness in voice due to incomplete glottic closure

 

The presentation of a lateralized, immobile cord in the paramedian position strongly suggests posterior cricoarytenoid muscle paralysis, typically due to recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroarytenoid: This muscle's paralysis would cause a bowed cord appearance but wouldn't result in a lateralized position. It affects voice quality by causing breathiness but through a different mechanism.

 

Option C. Cricothyroid: While this muscle's paralysis affects pitch control, it doesn't cause cord lateralization. The cord would appear lax and bowed rather than fixed in a paramedian position.

 

Option D. Lateral cricoarytenoid: This muscle's paralysis would affect adduction but wouldn't cause the cord to be fixed in a lateralized position. It would present with a more medial positioning defect.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand that posterior cricoarytenoid muscle paralysis results in a characteristic lateralized, paramedian position of the vocal cord, distinguishing it from other laryngeal muscle paralyses which present with different cord positions and mobility patterns.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS (Functional endoscopic sinus surgery) for failed conservative management 5 years ago. Uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation was done during the previous FESS. A DNE done now shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steroid irrigation and antihistamines

 

The next best step in management in this patient is steroid irrigation and antihistamines.

 

This patient who had previously undergone FESS 5 years ago for failed medical management now has nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip suggestive of acute rhinosinusitis.

 

Acute rhinosinusitis usually develops along with viral upper respiratory tract infection due to mucosal swelling causing obstruction of the sinus ostia. Persistent or worsening symptoms even after 10 days with fever and purulent discharge indicates secondary bacterial infection.

 

Treatment initially is symptomatic with -

 

  • First line of treatment - Nasal steroid irrigation, decongestants, and antihistamines
  • In cases of secondary bacterial infection antibiotics are indicated. Amoxyclav is the drug of choice.
  • Biological therapy is not used in the treatment of sinusitis. It may be used in cases of refractory polyp.
  • Revision surgery is indicated only when maximal medical therapy has failed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat Surgery: Indicated only if there are anatomical obstructions or complications that cannot be managed medically. In this case, the DNE shows patent ostia, so repeat surgery is not indicated without further evidence of structural issues.

 

Option B. Macrolides for 4 months: Could be considered for their anti-inflammatory properties in some chronic rhinosinusitis cases, but there is no mention of bacterial infection needing long-term antibiotics, making this less suitable than symptomatic management.

 

Option D. Biological Therapy: Mainly used for refractory cases with specific underlying conditions such as severe asthma or nasal polyps, which is not indicated here based on the provided scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip post-FESS with no current acute infection or structural issues, conservative management using steroid irrigation and antihistamines is recommended to manage inflammation and alleviate symptoms.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 213, 214

questions.text: In what situations does Gelle's test yield a negative result?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Otosclerosis

 

  • Gelle's test is negative when the ossicular chain is fixed as in case of otosclerosis.
  • Gelle's test –  Increased pressure in the ear canal by Siegel's speculum, pushes the tympanic membrane and ossicles inwards raising the intralabyrinthine pressure and reducing the mobility of the basilar membrane leading to decreased hearing. This is called as Gelle’s positive seen in normal and SNHL patients.
  • No change in hearing on applying pressure is Gelle’s negative, seen in ossicular chain fixation or discontinuity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSOM with Cholesteatoma: In case of CSOM with cholesteatoma, the pressure increased by the seigel’s speculum will directly push the cholesteatoma onto the ossicles (there is no fixation of ossicles here) and then there will be increased intralabyrinthine pressure. Hence Gelle will be positive.

 

Option B. Senile deafness: In case of senile deafness (presbycusis), there will be sensorineural hearing loss and it is due to natural aging of the hair cells. The ossicles will be mobile normally and hence Gelle will be positive.

 

Option C. Meniere’s disease: In case of Meniere’s disease also, the ossicles are not involved. On siegelisation, the inward pushed TM and ossicles will raise intralabyrinthine pressure, thereby making Gelle test positive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gelle’s test is instrumental in diagnosing conditions involving ossicular chain mobility. A negative Gelle's test, indicating ossicular fixation, is particularly indicative of otosclerosis, which is crucial for determining appropriate management strategies, including potential surgical interventions like stapedectomy for improving hearing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 24, 25

questions.text: Which staging is related to JNA? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radkowski

 

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that typically affects adolescent males. The staging system specifically related to JNA is the Radkowski staging system. This system helps to classify the extent of the tumor based on its location and spread:

 

  • Stage I: Tumor confined to the nasopharynx, nasal cavity, and may involve the paranasal sinuses.
  • Stage II: Tumor extends into the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • Stage III: Tumor invades the infratemporal fossa.
  • Stage IV: Tumor extends to the intracranial space, including the foramen magnum.

 

The Radkowski staging system helps in determining the surgical approach and prognosis for patients with JNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TNM: The TNM staging system is used for various carcinomas, especially solid tumors like those in breast cancer, lung cancer, etc. It stands for Tumor, Node, Metastasis.

 

Option B. Ann Arbor: The Ann Arbor staging system is used for lymphomas, particularly Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas.

 

Option D. Dukes: The Dukes staging system is used for colorectal cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Radkowski staging system is specifically used for staging Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA), assessing its extent and guiding treatment options.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man has arrived with a gradual swelling on the left side of his face persisting for two weeks. He had a prior incident of trauma involving wood, which occurred two months ago. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasal passages and paranasal sinuses reveals a mass within the subcutaneous tissue of the left cheek. Examination of a tissue sample obtained via biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, with positive staining observed using PAS and GMS methods. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis. GMS positive confirms this.

It is fungal infection which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs. 

Other Options:

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: This is a term historically used to describe aggressive midline facial granulomatous diseases, often linked to conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). It does not fit the biopsy findings or clinical scenario described here.

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Although the biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, the positive PAS and GMS staining suggests a fungal etiology, which is characteristic of Phycomycosis.

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: This is associated with IgG4-related disease, which presents with different clinical and histopathological findings, not typically involving PAS and GMS positive fungal elements.

Educational Objective:

Phycomycosis should be considered in patients with a history of trauma, swelling, and positive fungal stains (PAS and GMS), particularly if they have underlying conditions like diabetes or immunosuppression.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective tests for hearing do not require the active cooperation or response from the patient and are thus particularly useful in non-cooperative subjects such as young children or those who might simulate hearing loss.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system. It evaluates the mobility of the eardrum (tympanic membrane) and the conduction bones of the middle ear, providing useful information about middle ear pressure and fluid presence.

 

Other Option:

 

3. PTA (pure tone audiometry): This is a subjective test as it relies on the patient's response to pure tone stimuli. It is not included as an objective test because it requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. Subjective tests such as PTA, tuning fork tests, and speech audiometry depend on patient interaction and are susceptible to voluntary or involuntary response errors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective hearing tests like BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic information without the need for patient interaction, distinguishing them from subjective tests like Pure Tone Audiometry which rely on patient responses.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the ENT OPD with a complaint of nasal obstruction for the past two months. Her mother also reports foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On nasal endoscopy, the obstruction caused by crust formation is noted. She denies any bad smell. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atrophic Rhinitis

 

Explanation:

 

Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by chronic nasal obstruction, crust formation, and foul-smelling discharge. The patient’s denial of the bad smell indicates anosmia, which is common in atrophic rhinitis. This condition typically leads to the formation of crusts within the nasal cavity, causing obstruction and a foul odor noticed by others but not by the patient due to their reduced sense of smell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinitis Medicamentosa: This condition results from prolonged use of nasal decongestant drops (e.g., oxymetazoline or xylometazoline), leading to rebound nasal congestion, not crust formation or foul-smelling discharge.

 

Option B. Rhinosporidiosis: Caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, it presents with polypoid masses in the nasal cavity but not with crust formation and foul-smelling discharge.

 

 

Option D. Rhinoscleroma: Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, it presents with a hard, woody nose and specific histopathological findings, not just crust formation and foul-smelling discharge.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis presents with chronic nasal obstruction, crust formation, and foul-smelling discharge, often accompanied by anosmia.

questions.text: A post-COVID patient, who is a known diabetic, develops unilateral facial pain and loosening of teeth. Which investigation would you do to confirm the diagnosis on this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biopsy with histopathologic examination

 

The given scenario of a post-COVID diabetic patient with facial pain and loosening of teeth is suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. Among the given options, Biopsy with histopathologic examination would be the investigation for definitive diagnosis on this patient.

 

The primary reason that appears to be facilitating Mucorales spores to germinate in people with COVID-19 is

 

  1.  An ideal environment of low oxygen (hypoxia)
  2. high glucose (diabetes, new-onset hyperglycemia, steroid-induced hyperglycemia)
  3. Acidic medium (metabolic acidosis, diabetic ketoacidosis [DKA])
  4. High iron levels (increased ferritins)
  5. Decreased phagocytic activity of white blood cells (WBC) due to immunosuppression (SARS-CoV-2 mediated, steroid-mediated or background comorbidities) coupled with several other shared risk factors including prolonged hospitalization with or without mechanical ventilators

 

Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. It commonly occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus.

 

The presenting features are facial pain, numbness, loosening of teeth, conjunctival swelling, congestion, and blurry vision. When the disease spreads to the orbit, proptosis can be present. Due to invasion of the blood vessels, mucor fungus causes ischemic necrosis presenting as a black eschar, involving inferior turbinate, palate or the sinus. It can later spread to the frontal lobe of the brain and cavernous sinus.

 

 

 

Confirmation of diagnosis is by biopsy and histopathologic examination which shows aseptate fungi with thick-walled, ribbon-like, hyphae branching at right angles.

 

 

MRI is more sensitive to detecting orbital and nervous involvement than CT.

 

Contrast-enhanced MRI is the imaging technique of choice – black turbinate sign is seen

 

 

Post-contrast T1-weighted coronal MR image shows non enhancing soft tissue, “black turbinate sign,” within the left maxillary sinus (asterisk). The mucosa of the inferior turbinate and a portion of the left middle turbinate demonstrate focal lack of the enhancement (arrowheads).

 

Management

 

  • Antifungal therapy with Amphotericin B
  •  Surgical debridement of the affected tissues.
  •  Treatment of underlying cause
  • Control of blood sugars in diabetic patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): Useful for assessing the extent of disease, especially in identifying orbital and central nervous system involvement. It provides detailed images that help in planning the extent of surgical debridement.

 

Option C. Serum Ferritin: Elevated ferritin levels are commonly seen in mucormycosis due to the fungus’s use of iron from the host, which aids its growth. While not diagnostic, high ferritin levels can support the suspicion of mucormycosis in the right clinical context.

 

Option D. HbA1c (Glycated Hemoglobin): This test reflects long-term glucose control and is crucial in managing diabetic patients. Although it does not diagnose mucormycosis, poor glycemic control indicated by a high HbA1c value is a risk factor for the development of fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are critical for patients suspected of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis, especially in those with risk factors like diabetes and a recent COVID-19 infection. A biopsy with histopathologic examination is essential for confirming the diagnosis. This condition requires a multidisciplinary approach involving antifungal therapy, surgical debridement, and meticulous management of underlying conditions like diabetes to prevent serious complications and improve outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

  •  Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.
  •  Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.
  • Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.
  •  Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked 1 in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fossa of Rosenmuller

 

 

The image represented is the endoscopic view of lateral wall of the nasopharynx. Structure marked 1 is Fossa of Rosenmüller.

1 - FOSSA OF ROSENMULLER

2 - TORUS TUBARIUS

3 - POSTERIOR PHARYNGEAL WALL

4 - EUSTACHIAN TUBE OPENING

Lateral wall of nasopharynx contains Eustachian tube opening in the form of a bulge called torus tubarius and fossa of Rosenmüller lies behind this elevation (most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma)

 

The tubal tonsil is a small lymphoid tissue located at the tubal elevation near the opening of the eustachian tube.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubal Tonsil: Lymphoid tissue near the opening of the Eustachian tube but not visible as marked in this image.

 

Option C. Opening of Eustachian Tube: Located anterior to the Fossa of Rosenmuller, usually at the torus tubarius, not visible in the marked area.

 

Option D. Adenoid: Lymphoid tissue located on the posterior wall of the nasopharynx, not in the lateral wall and thus not visible in this specific view.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Fossa of Rosenmuller's familiarity is essential in nasopharyngeal examinations, especially in the context of identifying potential sites for nasopharyngeal carcinoma or other pathologies. Its recognition during endoscopy guides thorough inspection and appropriate clinical interventions.

choices.text: Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia without situs inversus

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with chronic productive cough and recurrent respiratory infections. His chest X-ray shows bronchiectasis with normal cardiac position. Semen analysis reveals immotile spermatozoa. [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia without situs inversus

 

Explanation: 

 

The image shows bronchiectasis with normal cardiac position (unlike the original which showed dextrocardia). Combined with the history of chronic respiratory symptoms and male infertility due to immotile sperm, this presentation is diagnostic of Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD) without situs inversus. While PCD with situs inversus is known as Kartagener syndrome, about 50% of PCD cases occur without situs inversus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kartagener syndrome: This requires the presence of situs inversus along with bronchiectasis and sinusitis. The normal cardiac position in this case rules out Kartagener syndrome.

 

Option C. Young syndrome: While it presents with bronchiectasis and azoospermia, the pathogenesis differs from PCD. In Young syndrome, sperm is produced but obstructed, unlike the immotile sperm in PCD.

 

Option D. Cystic fibrosis: Though it can present with bronchiectasis and male infertility, the mechanism is different. CF causes obstructive azoospermia due to congenital bilateral absence of vas deferens, not immotile sperm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand that Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia can occur with or without situs inversus, and when it occurs with situs inversus, it's specifically called Kartagener syndrome. The presence of bronchiectasis with immotile sperm but normal cardiac position differentiates PCD without situs inversus from Kartagener syndrome.

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.text: During the process of conducting a caloric test, what kind of nystagmus should one anticipate when using cold water irrigation?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side

 

In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side.

 

Fitzgerald-Hallpike test or bithermal caloric test procedure:

 

  • Patient is made to lie supine with the head tilted 30° forward so that the horizontal canal is vertical.

 

 

  • Irrigation stimulates the lateral/ horizontal semicircular canal which produces horizontal nystagmus.
  • Cold water induces nystagmus to the opposite side and warm water to the same side (remember mnemonic COWS: cold-opposite, warm-same)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side: This option is incorrect for cold water irrigation. Cold water causes the fluid in the horizontal semicircular canal to move in a way that induces nystagmus towards the opposite side, not the same side.

 

Option B. Vertical nystagmus towards the same side and Option D. Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side: Vertical nystagmus does not occur in caloric testing, as this test specifically stimulates the horizontal semicircular canal, inducing horizontal nystagmus. Vertical nystagmus is generally associated with different pathologies and is not a result of standard caloric testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The caloric test, particularly when using cold water, is designed to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canal, resulting in horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side. This test is critical for evaluating unilateral weaknesses in the vestibular system and helps in diagnosing conditions affecting balance and spatial orientation.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, page No. 45

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors and moving towards the cortex: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Auditory Cortex
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Cochlear Nucleus
  4. Lateral leminiscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Olivary complex
  7. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-3-6-4-5-7-1

 

The correct sequence of structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors (cochlea) and moving towards the auditory cortex, is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion: The auditory nerve fibers originate here.

 

3. Cochlear Nucleus: The auditory nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

6. Olivary complex: After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary complex.

 

4. Lateral lemniscus: From the superior olivary complex, the auditory signals travel via the lateral lemniscus.

 

5. Inferior colliculus: The lateral lemniscus projects to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

7. Medial geniculate body: The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

1. Auditory Cortex: Finally, the signals reach the auditory cortex (Area 41) in the temporal lobe for processing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

AUDITORY PATHWAY

 

E – Eighth nerve

 

C – Cochlear nucleus

 

O – Olivary complex (superior)

 

L – Lateral lemniscus

 

I – Inferior colliculus

 

M – Medial geniculate body

 

A – Auditory cortex

questions.text: The radiograph presented below has been taken to enhance the evaluation of the frontal sinus. What is the widely used term for this particular perspective?(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caldwell view

 

  • The above X ray shows the Caldwell view in which the frontal sinus is best seen.
  • Caldwell view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is taken with nose and forehead touching the film and X-ray beam is projected 15–20° caudally.
  • Structures seen are:
    1. Frontal sinuses (Best Visualization).
    2. Ethmoid sinuses.
    3. Maxillary sinuses.
    4. Frontal process of zygoma and zygomatic process of frontal bone.
    5. Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea.
    6. Superior orbital fissure.
    7. Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water's view: Primarily used for examining the maxillary sinuses and can also show the frontal sinuses but with less clarity than the Caldwell view.

 

Option C. Pierre's view: This is not a standard term in radiographic terminology.

 

Option D. Towne's view: Used to visualize the occipital bone and foramen magnum, not typically used for sinus examination.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a prolonged intubation patient, the following is seen. Staging for this is given by: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cotton Meyer

 

The images depict subglottic stenosis, which is a narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords, often due to prolonged intubation. This condition results from the high-pressure cuff of the endotracheal tube irritating the mucosa beneath the glottis. The Cotton Meyer classification system is used to stage subglottic stenosis based on the degree of airway narrowing:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radkowski: This staging system is used for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA), not subglottic stenosis.

 

Option C. AJCC: The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) staging is primarily used for cancer staging and does not apply to subglottic stenosis.

 

Option D. TNM: The TNM staging system is used for categorizing the extent of cancers, specifically focusing on tumor size (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M). It is not relevant for subglottic stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Subglottic stenosis resulting from prolonged intubation is staged using the Cotton Meyer classification, which grades the severity based on the percentage of airway narrowing

 

  • Grade 1: 0-50% stenosis
  • Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
  • Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
  • Grade 4: 100% stenosis (complete obstruction)

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given CT image. (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumatised superior turbinate

 

The superior turbinates form one of the three pairs of conchae in the nose and represent part of the labyrinth of the ethmoid bone, arising as bony projections from its posterior surface.

 

The air passage between the superior nasal concha and the lateral nasal wall is known as the superior meatus and forms part of the nasal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concha bullosa is a pneumatized middle turbinate.

 

 

Option C. Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell/ infraorbital ethmoidal air cells are ethmoid air cells located lateral to the maxillo-ethmoidal suture along the inferomedial orbital floor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumatisation of the superior turbinate, indicates the presence of air spaces within the turbinates, which can have implications for nasal physiology and potential sinus pathologies.

choices.text: Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane
Ossicular fixation without intact tympanic membrane

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented with hearing loss. On PTA, the amount of hearing loss was 56dB: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane

 

Otosclerosis is a common cause of progressive hearing loss, particularly in young adults and often worsens during pregnancy due to hormonal changes. The condition is characterized by abnormal bone growth around the stapes bone in the middle ear, leading to its fixation. This fixation prevents the stapes from vibrating in response to sound waves, thereby reducing the transmission of sound to the inner ear and causing hearing loss.

 

In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane (eardrum) typically appears normal upon examination. The hearing loss in otosclerosis is conductive, meaning it is due to a problem in the outer or middle ear, which transmits sound to the inner ear. A pure-tone audiogram (PTA) showing a 56dB hearing loss indicates significant conductive hearing impairment, consistent with otosclerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ossicular fixation without intact tympanic membrane: This condition is not typical of otosclerosis. Ossicular fixation in otosclerosis occurs with an intact tympanic membrane. A non-intact tympanic membrane would suggest a different pathology, such as chronic otitis media.

 

Option C. Erosion with intact tympanic membrane: Ossicular erosion with an intact tympanic membrane is not characteristic of otosclerosis. Ossicular erosion is more commonly seen in chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), particularly in its cholesteatoma form, which can erode the ossicles but usually involves perforation of the tympanic membrane.

 

Option D. Erosion without intact tympanic membrane: This is also not typical of otosclerosis. Erosion without an intact tympanic membrane again points towards chronic otitis media, especially with complications leading to ossicular erosion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otosclerosis often presents as progressive conductive hearing loss with an intact tympanic membrane, and the hearing loss can worsen during pregnancy. The classic finding is ossicular fixation, particularly of the stapes bone.

choices.text: Failure of migration of desquamated epithelium along posterior metal wall
Widening of meatus and facial nerve palsy might be seen

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about keratosis obturans? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

All of the above statements are true regarding keratosis obturans.

 

  • Collection of a pearly white mass of desquamated epithelial cells in the deep meatus is called keratosis obturans. This, by its pressure effect, causes absorption of bone leading to widening of the meatus so much so that facial nerves may be exposed and paralyzed.
  • Presenting symptoms may be pain in the ear, hearing loss, tinnitus and sometimes ear discharge. It may sometimes be associated with bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis.
  • On examination, the ear canal may be full of pearly white mass of keratin material disposed in several layers. Removal of this mass may show widening of bony meatus with ulceration and even granuloma formation.

 

 

Treatment

 

Keratotic mass is removed either by syringing or instrumentation, similar to the techniques employed for impacted wax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keratosis obturans is characterized by the accumulation of epithelial cells in the ear canal, leading to potential structural damage and associated symptoms. Its management requires careful removal of the buildup and monitoring for complications such as facial nerve palsy. Awareness of its association with bronchiectasis and sinusitis is crucial for comprehensive patient care.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image. (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenoid facies

 

The above given image shows adenoid facies. The characteristic features are visible which are: -

 

  • Elongated face with dull expression
  • Open mouth
  • Hitched up upper lip
  • Prominent upper teeth, which appear crowded
  • High arched hard palate
  • Pinched-in nose

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goldenhar syndrome: Typically presents with abnormalities of the eye, ear, and spine, none of which are visible in this image.

 

Option C. Horse facies: Characterized by an elongated face with prominent jaw structures, which does not match the features in the image.

 

Option D. Frog facies: Often includes a wide mouth and bulging eyes, which are not present in this child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoid facies can be recognized by characteristic features such as elongated face, open mouth posture due to nasal obstruction, hitched up upper lip revealing crowded upper teeth, and a pinched-in nose. It's associated with chronic adenoid hypertrophy, impacting the facial structure and respiratory function.

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient started having difficulty in breathing, and repeated attempts to extubate were unsuccessful. The most probable cause is: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

 

The clinical picture is suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

 

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal injury is commonly seen in total thyroidectomy.

 

  • Injury to both RLNs results in paralysis of intrinsic muscles of the larynx. The vocal cords cannot be abducted and thus come to lie in a median or paramedian position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid. This results in compromised laryngeal airway causing respiratory distress and stridor.
  • Tracheostomy is done as an emergency procedure to secure the airway.
  • Widening the respiratory airway without a permanent tracheostomy can be achieved by:
    1. Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)
    2. Partial arytenoidectomy
    3. Reinnervation procedures - these are used to innervate paralyzed posterior cricoarytenoid muscle by implanting a nerve-muscle pedicle of sternohyoid or omohyoid muscle with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi.
    4.  Thyroplasty type II – lateralisation of vocal cords

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Superior laryngeal nerve injury - This would primarily affect voice pitch and not typically cause significant breathing difficulty.

 

Option B. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury - Would lead to hoarseness but not usually severe breathing issues as one vocal cord would still function.

 

Option D. Hematoma - Although it can cause acute respiratory distress if it compresses the trachea, it does not typically lead to issues with extubation unless it is very severe.

 

Educational Objective:


Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury after thyroidectomy is a serious complication that can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction. Immediate recognition and management are crucial to ensure the safety and recovery of the patient.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 339

questions.text: The image given shows a patient who has undergone total laryngectomy due to laryngeal cancer. Identify the method of voice generation for this patient, as depicted in the provided image.(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tracheoesophageal prosthesis

 

The voice production modality depicted in the image is tracheoesophageal voice prosthesis.

 

The extended air from the trachea is diverted to the esophagus through a device that connects the trachea and esophagus in tracheoesophageal prosthesis. It also has a one-way valve that keeps food from entering into the trachea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrolarynx: Is a vibrating instrument that emits a low-pitched sound in the hypopharynx. The palate, tongue, and teeth then articulate it.

 

Option B. Chicago implant: Is a type of hearing aid.

 

Option D. Esophageal speech: The patient is trained to swallow air and slowly release it into the pharynx. 6-10 words can be spoken in a rough manner before re-swallowing the air.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheoesophageal prosthesis is a common and effective method for voice restoration following total laryngectomy. It relies on a surgically implanted device that directs air into the esophagus where vibrations are created for speech, significantly enhancing the quality of life for patients who have lost their natural voice box.

questions.text: What are the air cells located at the anterior most part of the anterior ethmoidal sinus called?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Agger nasi

 

The Agger nasi cells are the anterior-most air cells of the anterior ethmoid air cells. They are situated just above the attachment of the middle turbinate, making them critical landmarks in sinus surgery due to their proximity to the frontal sinus drainage pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulla ethmoidalis largest air cells in ethmoidal air sinus

 

Option B. Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell. They are significant due to their proximity to the optic nerve and the sphenoid sinus, posing a risk during sinus surgery.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell/ infraorbital ethmoidal air cells are ethmoid air cells located lateral to the maxillo-ethmoidal suture along the inferomedial orbital floor. Haller cells can impact the drainage of the maxillary sinus and are important to consider in imaging and surgical planning for sinus issues.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Agger nasi is the anterior-most air cells of anterior ethmoid air cells.
  • Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest air cells in ethmoidal air sinus
  • Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cells
  • Haller cells are ethmoid air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit and can affect the integrity and drainage of the maxillary sinus

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 152, 153

questions.text: From which of the following structures does the saccule develop? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pars inferior

 

The saccule develops from pars inferior.

 

Development of internal ear:

 

  • Development of the inner ear starts in the 3rd week of fetal life and is complete by the 16th week. Ectoderm in the region of hindbrain thickens to form an auditory placode, which is invaginated to form auditory vesicles or the otocyst. The latter then differentiates into the endolymphatic duct and sac; the utricle, the semicircular ducts; and saccule and the cochlea. Development of the phylogenetically older part of labyrinth—pars superior (semicircular canals and utricle) takes place earlier than pars inferior (saccule and cochlea).

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Saculus anterior - Not a term typically associated with the development of the ear's structures.

 

Option B. Saculus posterior - Similarly, this is not a recognized term in the developmental anatomy of the ear.

 

Option C. Pars superior - Incorrect, as this part contributes to the development of the semicircular canals and utricle, not the saccule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The developmental origins of the inner ear structures, such as the saccule from the pars inferior, is crucial for comprehending various auditory and vestibular functions, as well as pathologies associated with these areas.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 13

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trismus

 

  • Trismus is not a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space.
  • Parapharyngeal space is divided into 2 compartments by styloid process & its attachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vocal cord palsy: This could manifest due to involvement of the cranial nerves (CN IX, X, XI, XII) that are located in the post-styloid compartment. CN X (vagus nerve) palsy particularly can lead to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option C. Parotid swelling: Swelling in this region may occur as the post-styloid compartment is adjacent to the parotid gland and includes inflammatory processes that might extend into the parotid space.

 

Option D. Horner's syndrome: This syndrome may appear if the sympathetic chain, which runs through the post-styloid compartment, is affected by an infection or its related inflammatory processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presentation in a post-styloid abscess:

 

Bulge behind posterior tonsillar pillar.

 

  • Since post styloid compartment contains CN IX, X, XI, XII, their palsies may be seen.
  • Sympathetic chain involvement in this compartment will cause Horner's syndrome.
  • Swelling of the parotid region
  • No trismus or minimal trismus
  • General Symptoms - Fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis (due to spasm of prevertebral muscles) and signs of toxemia

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Contrast-enhanced CT scan neck – for extent of a lesion.
  • Magnetic resonance arteriography is useful if thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or aneurysm of the internal carotid artery is suspected.

 

Treatment

 

  • IV antibiotics with aerobic and anaerobic cover
  • Incision and drainage of abscess

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with vertigo, tinnitus and fluctuating hearing loss. The audiogram is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given image? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meniere’s disease

 

Given the patient's symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss, along with the audiogram showing a sensorineural hearing loss pattern with a dip at low to mid frequencies, the most likely diagnosis is Option B, Meniere’s disease.

 

Meniere’s disease is characterized by episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. The audiogram typically shows a sensorineural hearing loss that predominantly affects the low to mid frequencies, which is consistent with the audiogram provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo): Is a disorder arising from a problem in the inner ear. Symptoms include vertigo that is usually triggered by changes in the position of the head. It doesn't typically cause hearing loss, which we can see in the audiogram.

 

Option C. Vestibular neuronitis: Is an inflammation of the vestibular nerve, leading to vertigo and imbalance, but it does not usually affect hearing, so the audiogram would not show the hearing loss pattern we see here.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: Is a middle ear disease that usually presents with conductive hearing loss, particularly in younger adults, and it does not cause vertigo or tinnitus as primary symptoms. The audiogram for otosclerosis would show an air-bone gap, which is not present in the audiogram provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating hearing loss, and an audiogram showing low to mid frequency sensorineural hearing loss is Meniere’s disease.

choices.text: Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of these options is not a division originating from the external carotid artery within Kiesselbach's plexus? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries

 

Anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery are branches of ophthalmic artery which in turn is a branch of internal carotid artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphenopalatine artery: This artery is correctly identified as a branch of the maxillary artery, which itself is a major branch of the external carotid artery. It contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus by providing the septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Option C. Greater palatine artery: Also a branch of the maxillary artery, the septal branch of the greater palatine artery participates in forming Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Option D. Septal branch of superior labial artery: This artery, a branch of the facial artery (which originates from the external carotid artery), is part of the blood supply to Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ARTERIAL SUPPLY OF THE NOSE:

 

Internal carotid system -

 

  • Branches of ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

 

External Carotid System –

 

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).

 

KIESSELBACH'S PLEXUS -

 

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of greater palatine

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents in the ENT OPD with complaints of pain and discharge from the ear. Examination reveals the following findings. What is the best line of treatment? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clotrimazole ear drops

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with pain and discharge from the ear, and the examination shows black-headed filamentous growths on the otoendoscopic picture. This indicates a fungal infection, specifically otomycosis caused by Aspergillus niger. The best treatment for otomycosis is an antifungal agent.

 

Clotrimazole an antifungal and is typically used to treat otomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clotrimoxazole ear drops: Not an antifungal drug.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin ear drops: Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic and is used to treat bacterial infections. It does not have antifungal properties.

 

Option D. Wax softening ear drops: Wax softening ear drops contain ingredients like paradichlorobenzene, chlorbutol, and turpentine oil, which are used to soften ear wax. This treatment is irrelevant in the context of a fungal infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otomycosis, a fungal infection of the ear, caused by Aspergillus niger, should be treated with antifungal agents like Clotrimazole ear drops.

questions.text: Which of these structures are retained during radical neck dissection? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sublingual gland

 

In a radical neck dissection, the aim is to remove extensive lymphatic tissue potentially involved with malignancies, but the procedure generally spares certain non-lymphatic structures unless directly involved by the tumor. The sublingual gland, which is located under the floor of the mouth, is not typically removed during a radical neck dissection because it is not within the field of the lymph node groups that are typically excised. This gland remains intact unless the specific tumor pathology dictates otherwise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tail of parotid: The tail of the parotid may be removed if it is involved with the tumor or if the dissection needs to be extended to ensure comprehensive removal of cancerous tissues.

 

Option C. Submandibular gland: This gland is typically removed during radical neck dissections because it lies within the Level I lymph nodes, which are included in the dissection.

 

Option D. Level 2b lymph nodes: These are generally removed in a radical neck dissection, which traditionally includes the removal of lymph nodes from Levels I to V.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition Page No. 442; Stell and Maran 5th edition Page No. 710

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

Since the tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

 

 

Referred causes of otalgia. Pain is referred via CN V (teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, anterior two-thirds of tongue), C2,3 (cervical spine), CN IX (tonsil, base of tongue, elongated styloid process) and CN X (vallecula, pyriform fossa or larynx).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial nerve - This nerve primarily deals with facial expressions and some sensory functions of the face, not typically involved in referred pain from tonsillitis to the ear.

 

Option C. Trigeminal nerve - While it is a significant sensory nerve for the face, it is more commonly associated with referred pain from the teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, and anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via CN V).

 

Option D. Vagus nerve - Involved in sensory functions from the base of the tongue, vallecula, pyriform fossa, and larynx, not directly involved in referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Referred otalgia from tonsillitis is most commonly mediated through the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), highlighting the importance of the nerve's role in sensory transmission from the tonsils and tonsillar fossa to the ear.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 143, 144

questions.text: Identify the abnormal finding in this cochlear implant radiograph that requires immediate revision: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extracochlear electrode migration

 

Explanation: 

 

The abnormal finding shown is electrode migration outside the cochlear turns, which requires immediate surgical revision. When electrodes migrate out of the cochlea (extracochlear migration), it results in:

  • Loss of stimulation to specific frequency regions
  • Potential damage to surrounding structures
  • Ineffective auditory processing
  • Risk of facial nerve stimulation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Receiver-stimulator displacement While this can occur, it typically presents differently on imaging with obvious displacement of the internal receiver package from its bed.

 

Option C: Short electrode array insertion Partial insertion would be visible as a shortened array within the cochlea but would be identified during initial surgery.

 

Option D: Ground electrode disconnection Ground electrode issues typically present with device malfunction rather than visible radiographic changes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To recognize complications of cochlear implantation that require revision surgery, particularly electrode migration which can cause both functional failure and potential complications if left untreated.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presents with recurrent epistaxis and a nasopharyngeal mass showing significant intracranial and cavernous sinus extension on initial CECT. Which investigation would be most appropriate for surgical planning? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRI with contrast

 

Explanation: 

 

In cases of JNA with intracranial and cavernous sinus extension, MRI with contrast becomes the investigation of choice for surgical planning because:

  • Superior soft tissue resolution for evaluating intracranial extent
  • Better visualization of cavernous sinus involvement
  • Ability to differentiate tumor from retained secretions
  • Excellent delineation of dural involvement
  • No radiation exposure in young patients
  • Better assessment of post-operative changes if needed

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CECT: While excellent for initial diagnosis and bony erosion assessment, it provides limited soft tissue resolution for intracranial extension compared to MRI.

 

Option C. Digital subtraction angiography: Though useful for embolization planning, it doesn't provide adequate anatomical detail of intracranial extension needed for surgical planning.

 

Option D. CT angiography: Provides good vascular mapping but inferior to MRI for soft tissue delineation and intracranial spread assessment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand that while CECT is the initial investigation of choice for JNA, MRI becomes the preferred modality when there is intracranial extension, as it better delineates the relationship with critical neurovascular structures needed for surgical planning.

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaint of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve

 

The given clinical features of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth are suggestive of paralysis of the facial nerve.

 

Bell's palsy is defined as idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset.

 

Etiology –

 

  1. Viral infection  - herpes simplex, herpes zoster, EBV
  2. Vascular ischemia
  3. Heredity – narrow fallopian canal
  4. Autoimmune

 

Clinical features -

 

Onset is sudden. Patient is unable to close his eyes. On attempting to close the eye, the eyeball turns up and out (Bell phenomenon). Saliva dribbles from the angle of mouth. Face becomes asymmetrical. Tears flow down from the eye (epiphora). Pain in the ear may precede or accompany nerve paralysis. Some complain of noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis) or loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani). Paralysis may be complete or incomplete. Bell palsy is recurrent in 3–10% of patients.

 

 

Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigations.

 

Treatment of Bell's palsy -

 

  • Prednisolone is the drug of choice. If a patient reports within 1 week, the adult dose of prednisolone is 1 mg/kg/day divided into morning and evening doses for 5 days. Patient is seen on the fifth day. If paralysis is incomplete or is recovering, the dose is tapered during the next 5 days. If paralysis remains complete, the same dose is continued for another 10 days and thereafter tapered in next 5 days (total of 20 days).
  • Eye care to prevent keratitis
  • Analgesic for ear pain
  • Physiotherapy

 

Other Options:
