Option B. Trigeminal nerve: Mainly responsible for facial sensation, not motor control.

 

Option C. Oculomotor nerve: Primarily influences eye movement; paralysis typically results in ptosis and pupillary dilation, not facial drooping.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Affects swallowing and taste sensations at the back of the tongue; does not cause facial drooping or affect eye closure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prompt recognition and treatment of facial nerve paralysis are crucial for improving outcomes and preventing permanent damage. Treatment primarily involves medication to reduce inflammation and supportive care, especially for eye protection.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 103, 104

choices.text: Fast phase away from affected side

questions.text: In a patient with unilateral vestibular schwannoma causing complete vestibular loss, when performing caloric testing with cold water irrigation in the affected ear, what will be the expected direction of nystagmus? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No nystagmus

 

Explanation: 

 

In complete vestibular loss due to vestibular schwannoma, caloric stimulation of the affected ear will produce no response because the vestibular apparatus is completely non-functional. Cold water normally induces an inhibitory response causing nystagmus with fast phase to the opposite side, but when there's complete vestibular loss, there will be no nystagmus at all as the end organ cannot respond to thermal stimulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fast phase towards affected side: Incorrect because cold water normally produces nystagmus with fast phase away from the stimulated ear, and in complete vestibular loss, no nystagmus would occur at all.

 

Option B. Fast phase away from affected side: This would be the normal response in a healthy ear to cold caloric stimulation, but with complete vestibular loss, the ear cannot respond to caloric stimulation.

 

Option D. Vertical nystagmus: Caloric testing produces horizontal nystagmus in normal conditions. Vertical nystagmus is not a possible response to caloric testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand that in complete vestibular loss, caloric testing on the affected side produces no nystagmus due to complete loss of vestibular function, unlike in partial vestibular dysfunction where diminished responses might still be seen.

choices.text: Most commonly seen in adolescent male

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presents with profuse spontaneous nasal bleeding in ENT emergency. On physical examination: Patient seems pale having Hb: 9 gm/dl. On CECT: a mass is seen which pushes septum to the contralateral side & anterior bowing of maxillary antrum is seen. All of the given statements are true regarding this mass except?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Best treated by radiation

 

Explanation

 

The patient’s symptoms and examination findings, including profuse spontaneous nasal bleeding, pallor, and a mass pushing the septum to the contralateral side with anterior bowing of the maxillary antrum (Colman-Miller sign), are indicative of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). This condition is most commonly seen in adolescent males, can spread to the orbit and intracranially, but it is not best treated by radiation. The primary treatment for JNA is surgical resection, not radiation therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Most commonly seen in adolescent male: This is correct. JNA predominantly affects adolescent males.

 

Option B. Can spread to orbit: This is correct. JNA can extend into the orbit due to its aggressive nature.

 

Option D. Can spread intracranially: This is correct. JNA can invade the cranial cavity, leading to significant complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a condition that is most commonly seen in adolescent males and primarily treated with surgical resection, not radiation.

questions.text: Mucormycosis can be caused by following except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Broad spectrum antibiotics

 

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungal infection. This invades very rapidly to the surrounding tissue and even into orbit and then cranium, black eschars are formed.

 

It can be life-threatening if not attended immediately with surgical debridement, FESS and anti-fungal (Amphotericin-B) medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neutropenia: This condition involves a lowered count of neutrophils, a type of white blood cell that helps prevent and fight infections, making the body more vulnerable to fungal infections.

 

Option B. Uncontrolled Diabetes: High blood sugar levels can impair neutrophil function, making diabetics particularly susceptible to fungal infections like mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Prolonged or High-Dose Corticosteroid Therapy: Steroids suppress the immune system and reduce the body's ability to fight off fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risk factors for mucormycosis are:

 

  • Uncontrolled diabetes
  • Prolonged or high-dose corticosteroid therapy
  • Post - organ transplantation
  • Neutropenia
  • Intravenous drug use
  • Prolonged hospitalization
  • Immunodeficiency

questions.text: Which of these characteristics is not linked to superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sensorineural hearing loss

 

  • Conductive hearing loss is seen in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCDS).
  • “Third window” mechanism due to SCD and enlarged vestibular aqueduct. Schematic representations illustrate inner ear volume velocity with arrows -
    1. Normal anatomy allows volume velocity across the cochlear partition from the oval to the round window (two windows).
    2. Air conducted sound stimulation results in volume velocity from the stapes to be shunted toward the SCD (third window) and away from the cochlea, resulting in increased air-conduction thresholds at low frequencies and/or sound-induced vertigo (Tullio's phenomenon). Positive static pressure in the middle-ear cavity may result in ampullofugal fluid motion exciting the ampulla, resulting in nystagmus (Hennebert sign) and oscillopsia/vertigo.
    3. Elevated intracranial pressure from Valsalva against closed glottis (e.g., straining, heaving lifting) may result in ampullopetal endolymphatic fluid motion, inhibition of the ampulla, also leading to nystagmus (Hennebert sign) and oscillopsia/vertigo.
    4. Enlarged vestibular aqueduct (EVA) can also act as a third window, shunting volume velocity away from the cochlear partition and toward the widened vestibular aqueduct.

 

Gaze-evoked tinnitus or hyperacusis may also be seen.

 

 

  • High-resolution CT is the gold standard for identification of SSCD
  • Cervical VEMP sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing SSCDS ranges from 80% to 100%
  • Surgery is indicated only if symptoms are severe and disabling. Otherwise managed conservatively with medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaze dependent nystagmus: This can occur in SSCDS due to the abnormal transmission of fluid pressure waves through the "third window" created by the dehiscence, affecting the balance organs in the inner ear.

 

Option B. Positive Fistula test: This test, which involves applying pressure to the ear canal, can produce eye movements (nystagmus) or vertigo in cases of SSCDS due to the abnormal transmission of pressure to the inner ear.

 

Option D. Positive Tullio's phenomenon: This refers to sound-induced vertigo or nystagmus, which is a hallmark of SSCDS. The phenomenon occurs because sound vibrations lead to abnormal fluid dynamics in the inner ear due to the dehiscence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In SSCDS, conductive hearing loss is typical due to the additional pathway for sound and pressure transmission created by the dehiscence, not sensorineural hearing loss, which involves damage to the hair cells in the cochlea or the auditory nerve. Understanding these distinct characteristics helps in accurately diagnosing and managing the condition.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 2, Page no. 843-847

questions.text: Following a surgical procedure on the lateral aspect of the skull base, the patient experiences postoperative aspiration. However, there is no alteration in the patient's voice. What could be the explanation for this?(AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superior laryngeal nerve injury

 

  • The patient has an injury to the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN).
  • SLN motor supply – cricothyroid muscle → when affected causes change in voice only in high pitch
  • SLN sensory supply – Above level of vocal cords → when affected can cause aspiration.
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve doesn't provide either sensory or motor supply to the larynx so its lesion will not cause aspiration.
  • RLN supplies all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid > when affected will cause change in voice.
  • A high vagal injury will affect both SLN and RLN, hence can also be ruled out.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal nerve injury: This nerve does not primarily provide sensory or motor innervation to the larynx; its involvement would not typically result in aspiration.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury: Injury to this nerve would more likely affect the voice since it innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid. It would lead to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option D. High vagal injury: An injury here would affect both the SLN and the recurrent laryngeal nerve, likely causing symptoms in both voice and swallowing mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the superior laryngeal nerve, particularly its internal branch, is a plausible explanation for the patient's aspiration post-surgery, especially when there is no accompanying change in voice quality. This suggests that the sensory function above the vocal cords is compromised, increasing the risk of aspiration without necessarily affecting voice modulation handled by the external laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: In a patient with severe subglottic stenosis as shown in the chest X-ray (note the narrowing below the vocal cords), which emergency airway procedure would be most challenging to perform? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricothyroidotomy

 

Explanation: 

 

In subglottic stenosis, a cricothyroidotomy becomes particularly challenging because the stenosis lies immediately below the cricothyroid membrane. The narrowed, scarred airway in this region makes it difficult to:

  1. Identify the cricothyroid membrane accurately
  2. Create an adequate opening through the stenosed segment
  3. Insert and secure the airway tube through the narrowed passage
  4. Achieve adequate ventilation due to the underlying stenosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheostomy: While technically challenging, a tracheostomy can be performed below the level of stenosis where the tracheal anatomy is more normal, making it relatively more feasible than cricothyroidotomy.

 

Option C. Endotracheal intubation: Though difficult through the stenosed segment, can still be attempted with a smaller tube size guided by direct visualization.

 

Option D. Laryngeal airway: As it sits above the level of stenosis in the supraglottic region, it remains a viable temporary option for ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand that in subglottic stenosis, cricothyroidotomy becomes particularly challenging due to the anatomical distortion and narrowing at the precise location where the procedure needs to be performed, while other airway options might still be viable depending on the stenosis extent and location.

questions.text: Which structures pass between superior and middle constrictor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal Nerve)

 

The pharyngeal constrictor muscles are organized into three main parts: the superior, middle, and inferior constrictors. Each of these muscles plays a crucial role in the mechanics of swallowing and speech.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve passes between the superior and middle constrictor muscles. This is a key anatomical relationship to remember as it is crucial for the nerve supply to the pharynx.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eustachian Tube: Passes through the sinus of Morgagni, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option C. Superior Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the middle and inferior constrictors, not the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option D. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the inferior constrictor and the esophagus, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal nerve) and the stylopharyngeus muscle pass between the superior and middle constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus which lasts minutes to hours with accompanied nausea and vomiting. On investigation, there is endolymphatic hypertension present. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meniere’s disease

The patient's symptoms and the diagnostic finding of endolymphatic hypertension align with Meniere's disease. 

Characterized by episodes of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, lasting from minutes to hours. The symptoms are due to the accumulation of fluid in the inner ear (endolymphatic hydrops), leading to increased pressure within the endolymphatic system.

Other Options:

 Option B. Otosclerosis: A condition primarily affecting the bones of the middle ear, particularly the stapes. It causes conductive hearing loss, not typically associated with vertigo or tinnitus of the type seen in Meniere’s disease.

Option C. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV): Characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to changes in head position. It involves the dislodgment of otoliths within the inner ear, leading to brief, intense episodes of vertigo, without the auditory symptoms typical of Meniere's disease. 

Option D. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma): A benign tumor on the vestibular nerve, leading to progressive, unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disturbances. It usually does not cause episodic vertigo like Meniere's disease.

Educational Objective:

Meniere’s disease is a chronic condition that requires management of symptoms through lifestyle changes, medications to control vertigo, and sometimes more invasive treatments to manage fluid pressure in the inner ear.

questions.text: Identify the part of the cochlear implant marked? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grounding electrode

 

 

The marked part in the image is the grounding electrode, also known as the reference electrode. In a cochlear implant, the grounding electrode is usually implanted in the temporalis area. Its primary function is to serve as a reference point for electrical signals, ensuring accurate signal transmission and reducing noise interference during the processing of sound signals.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amplifier: An amplifier is not a distinct part of the cochlear implant. Instead, the sound processor amplifies and processes the sound signals before transmitting them to the receiver.

 

Option C. Receiver: The receiver in a cochlear implant is a component that lies under the skin and receives sound signals from the external transmitter. It is not the marked part in the image.

 

Option D. Electrode array: The electrode array is implanted inside the cochlea and is responsible for stimulating the auditory nerve. It directly interacts with the cochlea, unlike the grounding electrode that is positioned externally or at a different implant site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The grounding electrode or reference electrode in a cochlear implant is implanted in the temporalis area and is crucial for accurate signal transmission by providing a reference point for electrical signals.

questions.text: An audiogram of a 30-year-old female patient is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Otosclerosis

 

Based on the audiogram provided, which shows a conductive hearing loss pattern with a gap between the air conduction and bone conduction thresholds and considering the age of the patient, the most likely diagnosis is Otosclerosis. Carhart’s notch can also be noticed in the audiogram.

 

Otosclerosis is a condition affecting the bones in the middle ear, particularly the stapes, which becomes fixated, leading to conductive hearing loss. On an audiogram, this is typically indicated by a gap between the air conduction and bone conduction thresholds, particularly at lower frequencies. It is more commonly diagnosed in young adults, especially women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meniere’s disease: Is an inner ear disorder that can affect both hearing and balance. It is characterized by episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss. The audiogram might show a low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, especially in the early stages of the disease.

 

Option C. Noise-induced hearing loss: Is usually the result of chronic exposure to loud noises, which damages the hair cells in the cochlea. This type of hearing loss typically manifests as a 'notch' at the high frequencies on an audiogram, mostly at 4000 Hz.

 

Option D. Presbycusis: Is age-related hearing loss and is the cumulative effect of aging on hearing. It is characterized by a gradual and symmetrical sensorineural hearing loss, especially at higher frequencies on an audiogram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The audiometric profile of Otosclerosis: this typically presents as a conductive hearing loss with an air-bone gap on an audiogram, most often diagnosed in young adults, particularly females.

questions.text: The image of a drug is given below. It is used in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subglottic stenosis

 

The given drug is Mitomycin-C. It is used topically in the management of subglottic stenosis.

 

Mitomycin is an antibiotic that is isolated from the broth of Streptomyces caespitosus. This drug has demonstrated antitumor activity. Mitomycin belongs to a group of alkylating agents that work by cross-linking the complementary strands found in DNA. It also has antifibrotic property which prevents tissue scarring.

 

Thus, it can used to inhibit post-surgical scar formation and as a chemotherapeutic agent.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis - This fungal infection requires antifungal medications, not typically treated with Mitomycin-C.

 

Option C. Adenoidectomy - A surgical procedure to remove adenoids; does not involve the use of Mitomycin-C.

 

Option D. Tympanoplasty - Surgical repair of the eardrum, where Mitomycin-C is not routinely used.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Mitomycin-C is particularly effective in preventing the recurrence of subglottic stenosis after surgery due to its antifibrotic properties, making it a critical adjunct in surgical procedures involving the airway.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 3, Page No. 1088

questions.text: Identify the air cell marked with red arrow in the CT scan of the nose and paranasal sinus: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bulla Ethmoidalis

 

The red arrow in the CT scan points to a large air cell within the ethmoid sinus, which is the Bulla Ethmoidalis. The Bulla Ethmoidalis is the largest and most constant air cell in the anterior ethmoid sinus. It is centrally located within the ethmoid labyrinth and serves as a key landmark in endoscopic sinus surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Agger Nasi Cell: The Agger Nasi cell is the most anterior ethmoidal air cell, situated anteriorly and superiorly to the insertion of the middle turbinate.

 

 

Option C. Haller Cell: Haller cells are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit. They are located inferiorly, near the orbit floor.

 

 

Option D. Onodi Cell: The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that extends into the sphenoid bone and is situated near the optic nerve.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bulla Ethmoidalis is the largest and most constant air cell in the anterior ethmoid sinus.

questions.text: Identify the blue line shown in the below picture:(AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ohngren's line

 

  • Ohngren's line is an imaginary line passing through the medial canthus of the eye and angle of mandible.
  • It is used for classification of maxillary carcinoma.
  • Growth situated above the plane - Suprastructure - Poor Prognosis
  • Growth situated below the plane - Infrastructure - Good Prognosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frankfurt horizontal line, the line passing through the inferior border of infraorbital rim and superior border of external auditory canal, is one of the most widely used intracranial landmarks in cephalometric analysis.

 

 

Option B. Donaldson line is an imaginary line drawn posteriorly from the course of the horizontal semicircular canal, used to identify endolymphatic sac during endolymphatic sac decompression surgery for meniere’s disease.

 

 

Option C. According to Lederman’s classification, 2 horizontal lines called lines of Sebileau pass through orbit floor and maxillary sinus, producing Suprastructure, mesostructure and infrastructure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ohngren's line is used to classify maxillary carcinomas into suprastructure and infrastructure based on their location relative to the line, which is critical for determining the prognosis and approach for surgical intervention.

questions.text: What is the surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal called? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meatoplasty

 

The surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal is meatoplasty.

 

It is performed in combination with all canal wall down procedures like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, for the treatment of middle ear disease such as cholesteatoma. The widened meats help easily visualize and access the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning.

 

It is also done as an isolated procedure in elderly people with sagging auricle. Sagging auricle causes obstruction to the meatus leading to retention of wax and difficulty in hearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane for improved hearing.

 

Option C: Myringoplasty refers to the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane only.

 

Option D: A cosmetic or reconstructive procedure aimed at correcting deformities or defects of the external part of the ear (pinna).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meatoplasty is an important surgical option for managing conditions that require improved access to the ear canal and middle ear, particularly in managing chronic ear diseases or anatomical changes that impact ear function.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 32, 457, 463
